text: To set the answer up, I'll give you a super brief history of Make Time. And for over a decade, John and I have been, in quotes, designing time as part of our work with startups, helping them find or expand product market fit. So, we developed a design sprint at Google Ventures, which the Sprint book is about.
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Lenny asks Jake what most people get wrong when they're trying to become more productive. Jake begins by explaining the background of their book Make Time and how it emerged from their work with startups. He describes how they've been 'designing time' for over a decade through their work helping startups find product-market fit, which led to developing design sprints at Google Ventures.
vocabulary_highlights: find or expand product market fit
text_ko: 답변을 준비하기 위해, Make Time의 간단한 역사를 말씀드릴게요. 존과 저는 10년 넘게 스타트업과 함께 일하면서, '시간을 디자인하는' 작업을 해왔어요. 그 과정에서 제품 시장 적합성(product market fit)을 찾거나 확장하는 데 도움을 줬죠. 그래서 구글 벤처스에서 디자인 스프린트(design sprint)를 개발하게 되었고, 그에 관한 책이 바로 '스프린트(Sprint)'예요.
text_zh: 先简单说说《腾出时间》这本书的背景。十多年来，我和约翰一直在做"时间设计"这件事，帮助初创公司找到或扩大产品市场匹配度(product market fit)。所以我们在谷歌风投开发了设计冲刺(design sprint)方法，《冲刺》那本书讲的就是这个。
text_es: Para contextualizarte, te voy a dar un resumen súper breve de la historia de Make Time. Durante más de una década, John y yo hemos estado, entre comillas, diseñando el tiempo como parte de nuestro trabajo con startups, ayudándoles a encontrar o expandir el ajuste producto-mercado (product market fit). Así que desarrollamos un sprint de diseño (design sprint) en Google Ventures, que es de lo que trata el libro Sprint.
key_sentence: We designed time to help startups find or expand product market fit.

text: So, even though we are not productivity gurus, this hasn't been like this thing we were doing forever, it's not our full-time job, but we thought we want to share this framework. So, Make Time, the book and the blog that proceeded it was just kind this side project to share what we learned. And yeah, it seems like it is resonated with a bunch of people.
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Jake continues explaining the origin story of their Make Time book. He emphasizes that they aren't traditional productivity experts - this wasn't their main career focus, but rather emerged as a side project to share practical lessons they discovered while working with startups on design sprints and applying those insights to their personal productivity.
vocabulary_highlights: resonated with a bunch of people
text_ko: 저희는 생산성 전문가(productivity gurus)는 아니고, 오래전부터 해오던 일도 아니고 전업으로 하는 일도 아니었어요. 다만 이 프레임워크(framework)를 다른 사람들과 나누고 싶었어요. 그래서 Make Time이라는 책과 그보다 먼저 시작한 블로그는 우리가 배운 걸 공유하려는 사이드 프로젝트(side project)였고요. 그런데 의외로 많은 분들에게 공감을 얻은 것 같아요.
text_zh: 所以，虽然我们不是什么生产力大师，这也不是我们一直在做的事情，也不是我们的全职工作，但我们觉得想把这套方法分享出来。所以，《腾出时间》这本书，还有之前的博客，就是我们的一个副业项目，想分享一下我们学到的东西。看起来确实引起了很多人的共鸣。
text_es: Entonces, aunque no somos gurús de la productividad, esto no es algo que hayamos estado haciendo toda la vida, no es nuestro trabajo de tiempo completo, pero pensamos que queríamos compartir este marco de trabajo (framework). Así que Make Time, el libro y el blog que lo precedió, fue como este proyecto paralelo para compartir lo que aprendimos. Y sí, parece que ha conectado con un montón de gente.
key_sentence: Make Time was a side project that resonated with a bunch of people.

text: Our perspective is basically that those are the defaults. Just like our software that we use, apps that we use have defaults, those are the defaults of life, of the companies that we work in, the culture that we live in. And so, the solution is actually to change those defaults and to really flip this way of thinking on its head.
speaker: John Zeratsky
context: Lenny asks about what people get wrong with productivity, and John explains their core philosophy. He argues that most productivity advice focuses on being more efficient at existing tasks (emails, meetings), but their approach is about changing the fundamental defaults of how we structure our time, similar to how software has default settings that can be customized.
vocabulary_highlights: flip this way of thinking on its head
text_ko: 저희 관점은 그런 것들이 바로 기본값(defaults)이라는 거예요. 우리가 쓰는 소프트웨어(software)나 앱(apps)에 기본값이 있듯이, 삶이나 우리가 다니는 회사, 우리가 속한 문화에도 그런 기본값이 있다는 뜻이에요. 그래서 해결책은 그 기본값을 바꾸고, 이런 사고방식을 완전히 뒤집는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们的观点其实很简单，那些就是默认设置。就像我们用的软件、APP都有默认设置一样，这些就是生活的默认设置，包括我们工作的公司、我们身处的文化环境。所以解决方案其实就是要改变这些默认设置，把这种思维方式彻底颠覆过来。
text_es: Nuestra perspectiva es básicamente que esas son las configuraciones por defecto. Igual que el software que usamos, las aplicaciones que manejamos tienen sus ajustes predeterminados, esos son los defaults de la vida, de las empresas donde trabajamos, de la cultura en la que vivimos. Entonces, la solución en realidad es cambiar esos defaults y darle la vuelta completa a esta forma de pensar.
key_sentence: The solution is to flip this way of thinking on its head.

text: The idea of the busy bandwagon is just this expectation that everybody's busy. And in the United States, there's kind of this thing that I think if you travel abroad and talk to people for a while, then you come back, you'll notice, which is like if you ask someone, 'Hey, how's it going? What are you up to?' And they'll be like, 'Oh man, I'm busy.'
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Lenny asks about the concepts of 'busy bandwagon' and 'infinity pools' that prevent people from making time for important things. Jake explains the busy bandwagon as a cultural expectation in the US where being busy is the default response and almost a badge of honor, creating internal pressure to always appear busy and reactive to others' demands.
text_ko: 바쁜 밴드왜건(busy bandwagon)이라는 생각은 결국 모두가 바쁘다고 기대하는 거예요. 미국에는 그런 경향이 있는데요, 해외에 좀 다녀와서 사람들과 얘기해 보면 돌아오면 더 확실히 느껴져요. 예를 들어 '요즘 어때? 뭐 해?'라고 물어보면 다들 '아, 나 바빠요'라고들 해요.
text_zh: 忙碌跟风(busy bandwagon)这个概念就是说，大家都觉得每个人都应该很忙。在美国，有这么一种现象，我觉得如果你出国待一段时间，跟当地人聊聊，然后回来你就会发现——就是当你问别人"嘿，最近怎么样？在忙什么呢？"他们就会说"哎呀，忙死了。"
text_es: La idea de esta moda de estar ocupado es simplemente esa expectativa de que todo el mundo está súper ocupado. Y en Estados Unidos, hay como una cosa que creo que si viajas al extranjero y hablas con la gente un rato, y luego regresas, te das cuenta, que es como si le preguntas a alguien: "Oye, ¿cómo te va? ¿Qué tal todo?" Y te van a decir: "Ay, hermano, estoy ocupadísimo."
key_sentence: The busy bandwagon creates an expectation that everyone is busy.

text: And so, when you put these two things together, the busy bandwagon and the infinity pool, you kind of have this, it's like a flywheel, but bad. You feel like you really need to be busy, you really need to be on top of everything. And then, you've got this whole collection of apps and services and products there that are ready to pounce on that.
speaker: John Zeratsky
context: John is explaining how the busy bandwagon (cultural pressure to be busy) combines with infinity pools (endlessly refreshing content like social media and email) to create a destructive cycle. He describes how these two forces work together - the internal pressure to stay busy meets apps designed to capture attention, creating what he calls 'a flywheel, but bad.'
text_ko: 그래서 이 두 가지, 바쁜 밴드왜건(busy bandwagon)과 인피니티 풀(infinity pool)을 합치면, 말하자면 플라이휠(flywheel) 같은 효과가 나는데 좋은 플라이휠이 아니라 안 좋은 쪽이에요. 정말 바쁘지 않으면 안 될 것 같고, 모든 걸 다 챙겨야 한다는 압박을 느끼게 돼요. 그러면 그걸 노리듯 수많은 앱·서비스·제품이 바로 달려들 준비를 하고 있어요.
text_zh: 所以说，当你把这两个东西放在一起——忙碌的从众心理(busy bandwagon)和无限信息池(infinity pool)，就形成了一种恶性循环，就像飞轮(flywheel)一样，但是是坏的那种。你会觉得自己必须得忙起来，什么事都得跟上节奏。然后呢，就有一大堆应用、服务和产品在那儿等着，随时准备"收割"你。
text_es: Entonces, cuando juntas estas dos cosas, el rollo de estar siempre ocupado y esa piscina infinita de contenido, tienes como una especie de rueda que se retroalimenta, pero para mal. Sientes que de verdad necesitas estar ocupado todo el tiempo, que tienes que estar al día con todo. Y ahí tienes un montón de apps, servicios y productos listos para aprovecharse de eso.
key_sentence: The busy bandwagon and infinity pool create a flywheel, but bad.

text: At any given point in time, I probably give myself a B to B-, and sometimes it's a C and sometimes it's a D, and sometimes it's an A, and I'm really plugging away, but it's totally an ongoing challenge. So, I'm not going to sit here and say, yeah, just follow me with a drone for 48 hours and you'll think that's exactly how you should do things.
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Lenny asks Jake and John about their own productivity and how well they follow their Make Time framework. Jake gives an honest assessment of his own performance, rating himself between B- and D most days. He emphasizes that productivity is an ongoing challenge and he doesn't want to present himself as having it all figured out perfectly.
text_ko: 지금 이 순간 제 자신을 평가해보면 보통 B에서 B- 정도라고 생각해요. 가끔은 C, 때로는 D일 때도 있고, 또 어떤 땐 A를 준다고 느낄 때도 있어요. 정말 열심히 하고 있지만 계속되는 도전이에요. 그래서 제가 여기서 '48시간 동안 드론(drone)으로 저만 따라다니면 이게 바로 일하는 방식의 정답이라고 생각하게 될 거예요'라고 말하진 않겠어요.
text_zh: 不管什么时候，我给自己打分的话，大概就是B到B-吧，有时候是C，有时候是D，偶尔能拿个A，我一直在努力，但这真的是个持续的挑战。所以我不会坐在这儿跟你说，嘿，你跟着我48小时，然后就觉得我做的就是标准答案。
text_es: En cualquier momento dado, probablemente me pondría un B o B-, y a veces es un C y a veces un D, y de vez en cuando un A, y sigo dale que dale, pero es un desafío constante. Así que no voy a sentarme aquí y decir, sí, sígueme con un dron por 48 horas y vas a pensar que así es exactamente como debes hacer las cosas.
key_sentence: I'm always plugging away, facing ongoing challenges with my productivity.

text: The notion what the highlight is, start your day out and you imagine it's the end of the day, you're looking back on the day. If someone asked you, 'What was the highlight of your day,' what would you say? What do you want to say at the end of today was the highlight of today?
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Jake is explaining the concept of a 'highlight' - the central component of their Make Time framework. This is about choosing one main thing you want to accomplish each day by imagining what you'd want to tell someone was the best part of your day. It's the anchor that helps you structure your time around what truly matters to you.
text_ko: 하루를 시작할 때 마치 그날이 이미 끝나서 되돌아보고 있는 것처럼 상상해 보세요. 누군가가 "오늘의 하이라이트가 뭐였어요?"라고 물으면 뭐라고 답하고 싶으세요? 오늘 하루가 끝날 때 "오늘의 하이라이트는 이거였어요"라고 말하고 싶게 만드는 건 뭘까요?
text_zh: 这个概念就是说，一天开始的时候，你想象一下今天已经结束了，你在回顾这一天。如果有人问你"今天最棒的事情是什么"，你会怎么回答？今天结束的时候，你希望能说什么是今天的亮点？
text_es: La idea es esta: empiezas tu día imaginándote que ya es el final del día y estás viendo hacia atrás. Si alguien te preguntara "¿Qué fue lo mejor de tu día?", ¿qué responderías? ¿Qué quieres poder decir al final de hoy que fue lo mejor del día?
key_sentence: Looking back on the day, what was the highlight you want to remember?

text: So, most days, the first half of the day before lunch is my focus time, and I protect that very, very intensely, and then use that time to work on whatever my highlight is.
speaker: John Zeratsky
context: John is describing his personal implementation of the Make Time framework as a venture capitalist. He explains how he structures his calendar to prioritize focused work time for his daily highlight, despite the naturally chaotic and meeting-heavy environment of VC work. This shows how to apply the highlight concept in a demanding professional context.
text_ko: 보통 점심 전 오전이 제 집중 시간이어서 그 시간을 정말 철저히 지켜요. 그 시간엔 그날의 하이라이트(highlight)에만 집중해요.
text_zh: 所以呢，大部分时候，上午到午饭前这段时间是我的专注时间，我会非常非常严格地保护这个时间段，然后用这个时间来处理我当天的重点工作。
text_es: Entonces, la mayoría de los días, toda la mañana hasta el almuerzo es mi tiempo de concentración, y lo cuido muchísimo, y uso ese tiempo para trabajar en lo que sea mi prioridad del día.
key_sentence: I protect that very, very intensely focus time for my highlight work.

text: This thing, I think we basically are steered toward becoming reaction machines and this notion of, 'I'm going to have an empty inbox. I'm going to do every task. I'm going to be a fast responder, I'm going to be in every meeting. I'm going to do that because I want to help other people, and that's the way it works.'
speaker: Jake Knapp
context: Jake is explaining why people struggle with productivity and fall into reactive patterns. He describes how the desire to be helpful and responsive leads people to become 'reaction machines' - constantly responding to others' demands rather than focusing on their own important work. This reactive mode prevents people from doing meaningful, proactive work.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 결국 우리를 반응만 하는 기계(reaction machines)로 몰아가는 것 같아요. '인박스를 비워야 해(inbox zero). 모든 업무를 다 해내고, 답장은 빨리 하고, 모든 회의에 참석해야 해. 남을 도우려는 마음에서 그런 거고, 그게 정상적인 방식이라는 생각' 말이에요.
text_zh: 我觉得这事儿吧，我们基本上都被推着变成了反应机器，就是那种想法——"我要把邮箱清空，每个任务都要做，要秒回消息，每个会都要参加。我这么做是因为想帮助别人，觉得就应该这样。"
text_es: Mira, creo que básicamente nos están convirtiendo en máquinas de reaccionar, con esa mentalidad de "voy a tener el correo vacío, voy a hacer todas las tareas, voy a responder súper rápido, voy a estar en todas las reuniones. Lo voy a hacer porque quiero ayudar a los demás, y así es como funciona esto."
key_sentence: We are steered toward becoming reaction machines and fast responders.
